questions.text: How often does your weekly grocery shop end up with unused items that go to waste?

options.text: Almost every week – it's frustrating.
Every other week.
Rarely, I'm pretty careful.
I don't really track it.

questions.text: Think of the last thing you had to throw away. What was it most likely?

options.text: Fresh greens or herbs (lettuce, spinach, cilantro).
Leftovers from a meal I got tired of.
Fruits that ripened too fast.
That 'special' ingredient I bought for one recipe.

questions.text: Let's talk numbers. What's your 'waste line' – the monthly cost of thrown-away food you're comfortable with?

options.text: $0 – I want to eliminate waste.
Under $20.
$20-$50 – but I'd like it lower.
I avoid thinking about it, honestly.

questions.text: Be brutally honest. Your actual waste is probably closer to...

options.text: 2-3 times that amount. It adds up silently.
About right, but it feels like more.
I really have no idea.

questions.text: What's more scarce for you: the money lost to waste, or the time/mental energy to plan to prevent it?

options.text: The money – every dollar counts.
The time/energy – I'm too busy to plan perfectly.
Both are equally scarce!
I'm a pragmatic planner who hates inefficiency.
I'm an adventurous cook who hates being bored.
I'm a conscientious person who tries to reduce waste.
I'm just someone who wants easy, good food.

questions.text: You've just described the exact problem we exist to solve. Are you ready to finally fix it?
